title: Are personalised diets the best way to be healthy?
intro: Many diets claim to improve health or help you lose weight, recent research shows that what counts is not what you eat but how your body reacts . Neil and Sam discuss how microbes matter when it comes to food, and teach some related vocabulary.
this_week_question: How long exactly is the average adult’s gut?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: (informal) intestines; long tube inside the body which starts below the stomach and helps digest food
tiny, microscopic organisms living inside the human body
unit measuring the amount of energy that food provides
weak and difficult to believe; not convincing
be very easy to notice, in a positive sense

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Sam.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I’m Neil.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: In recent years new diets with names like ‘vegan’, ‘keto’ and ‘paleo’ have become very popular. Are you a vegetarian, Neil? Do you follow any particular diet?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I eat lots of fresh fruit and vegetables and only a little meat from time to time.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Well, while many diets claim to improve health or help you lose weight, recent research shows that what counts is not what you eat but how your body reacts .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, and that reaction doesn’t happen where you might think – not in the brain, or tongue, or even the stomach, but in the gut – another name for the intestines - the long tube inside your body which digests food.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Inside everyone’s gut are millions of microbes – tiny living organisms, too small to see without a microscope. Some of them are good for us, some bad.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Microbes help digest food, but they influence our bodies more than we know. Think of them as chemical factories that cause our individual reaction to the food we eat.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: This mix of gut microbes is unique and different for everyone, even identical twins.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And it’s the reason why some doctors now recommend a personalised diet, one that perfectly fits your own unique combination of microbes.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: We’ll hear more soon, but first I have a question for you, Neil, and it’s about the gut - the tube which includes the large and small intestine. It’s very long - but how long exactly is the average adult’s gut? Is it: a) 3.5 metres? b) 5.5 metres? or, c) 7.5 metres?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, everybody is different of course, but I’ll say on average the gut is b) 5.5 metres long.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: OK, Neil, I’ll reveal the answer later in the programme.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Among the first to investigate gut microbes was Dr Tim Spector, author of bestselling book, The Diet Myth. He wanted to check whether the dietary advice he had heard and believed, advice like ‘eat little and often’ or ‘avoid fat’, was really true.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Listen as Dr Spector explains how he started to doubt some of this advice - ‘food myths’, he calls them - to BBC Radio 4 programme, The Life Scientific:

transcript.author: Tim Spector
transcript.text: All these so-called myths that I’d believed, whether it was about calories , about fats, when to eat, how to eat, were based on flimsy or no evidence, very old, very poor quality, and had been repeated so much that people didn’t think to question them.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: One of the food myths Dr Spector questioned was counting calories – the units which measure the amount of energy food provides.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: He discovered that much of the dietary advice he had heard was either incorrect or based on flimsy evidence. If evidence is flimsy , it’s weak and unconvincing.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: As Dr Spector questioned these food myths, he remembered an earlier study involving identical twins, pairs of brothers or sisters with the same genes.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: It was the surprising differences in weight between one twin and another that made Dr Spector realise that no two people have the same gut – even identical twins’ guts are different.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But, as he told BBC Radio 4’s, The Life Scientific, the discovery came in a very smelly way – by asking his volunteers to send samples of their poo in the post!

transcript.author: Tim Spector
transcript.text: We collected lots of these samples, sequenced them, and looked at twins where one was overweight and one was skinny … and we found in every case, the skinnier twin had a more diverse microbiome, greater numbers of different species and they also nearly always had high numbers of a couple of microbes that just stuck out of the crowd – and one was called christensenella and the other was called akkermansia.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Although genetically identical, one twin was overweight, while the other twin was skinny , or very thin.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Because the weight difference could not be explained genetically, Dr Spector suspected the microbes in the skinnier twin’s gut held the answer: the more diverse someone’s microbes, the better their gut was at digesting food, regulating fat and maintaining health.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Two microbes, christensenella and akkermansia , were especially effective. Dr Spector says these microbes stuck out of the crowd , meaning they were easy to notice for their positive effect.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And since everyone’s microbes are different, it follows that a personalised diet which selects the friendliest food for your gut, is best. Right, and all this talk of eating is making me hungry, so tell me, Sam, was my answer to your question, right?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Ah yes, I asked about the length of the gut in the average adult.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I said it was 5.5 metres.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Which was… the correct answer! Well done, Neil – that took ‘guts’, which is the second meaning of the word: courage.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, let’s recap the vocabulary we’ve learned starting with gut – an informal word for the intestines, the tube which digests food from the stomach.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Microbes are microscopic organisms living inside the body.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A calorie is a unit measuring how much energy food provides.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: If an argument or evidence is flimsy , it’s weak and hard to believe.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A skinny person is very thin.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And finally, if something sticks out of the crowd , it’s noticeable in a good way.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Unfortunately, our six minutes are up, but remember: look after your gut, and your gut will look after you! Goodbye!
